TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE . She is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
A.

On DATE the applicant was convicted of an offence and committed to a psychiatric institution pursuant to ORG . Following the entry into force of LAW DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) the applicant continued to be detained as a “ restricted patient ” under sections DATE and CARDINAL of the DATE Act .

On DATE the applicant was conditionally discharged but she was recalled on DATE by warrant of the Secretary of ORG pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW . She was then detained at a medium secure unit until DATE when she was transferred to another ward from where , on DATE , she was moved to a community - based ward .

DATE and DATE , the continuing grounds for applicant ’s detention were reviewed twice by ORG ( “ MHRT ” ) . In DATE the applicant made a third application to the ORG , but then changed her mind and withdrew it . On DATE she made a further application which was received by the MHRT on DATE By letter dated DATE , the ORG informed the applicant ’s solicitor that his client had made an application to have her case reviewed . The solicitor took instructions from the applicant and applied for legal aid on her behalf . Legal aid was granted by telephone on DATE , and expenditure of up to GBP CARDINAL was approved in respect of an independent psychiatric report .

The following day the applicant ’s solicitor wrote to a consultant psychiatrist , asking him to prepare a report . The psychiatrist informed that applicant ’s solicitor that he was not free to examine the applicant until DATE . On DATE , therefore , the applicant ’s solicitor wrote to the ORG asking that the case should not be listed for hearing until DATE to allow for the preparation of the independent psychiatric report . The appointment with the psychiatrist had subsequently to be postponed until DATE .

The ORG received the statutory reports , namely ORG on DATE , and ORG on DATE . Copies of these reports were sent to the applicant ’s solicitors , who received them on CARDINAL and CARDINAL DATE respectively . ORG comments on these CARDINAL reports were received by the ORG on DATE , and forwarded to the applicant ’s solicitors on DATE and DATE .

On DATE the applicant ’s solicitor wrote to the psychiatrist instructed on behalf of the applicant to remind him that the independent psychiatric report was still outstanding . The report , dated DATE , was finally received by the applicant ’s solicitor on DATE . The applicant claims that her solicitors wrote to the ORG on DATE , but the ORG has no record of this letter . According to the applicant , the ORG then telephoned her solicitor on DATE suggesting a hearing date of DATE , but the applicant ’s solicitor rejected this date since he was not available . It is not in dispute that the solicitor wrote to the ORG on DATE , reminding the tribunal that the matter was outstanding and enclosing the psychiatric report prepared on the applicant ’s behalf .

The case was then listed for hearing on DATE . Copies of the psychiatric report prepared on behalf of the applicant were sent to the other parties for their comments , and these comments were sent to the applicant ’s solicitors before the hearing .
On DATE the ORG decided not to recommend the applicant ’s discharge .
B. Relevant domestic law and practice

Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) empowers a ORG to order a person ’s admission to and detention in a specified hospital ( a “ hospital order ” ) . The court can only make a hospital order if it is satisfied on the evidence of CARDINAL registered medical practitioners that the offender is mentally disordered , that the disorder is of a nature or degree which makes it appropriate for the person to be detained in a hospital for medical treatment and that a hospital order is the most suitable method of disposing of the case .

Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act empowers a ORG , when making a hospital order , to make a restriction order without limit of time . A restriction order may be made if it appears to the court , having regard to the nature of the offence , the offender ’s antecedents and the risk of her committing further offences if set at large , that it is necessary for the protection of the public from serious harm to make the order .

Under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act a person who is subject to a hospital order and restriction order ( “ a restricted patient ” ) , and who is detained in hospital , can apply to a ORG ( “ MHRT ” ) after being detained for DATE . After CARDINAL months’ detention the patient can re - apply DATE . Under section CARDINAL of the DATE Act the Secretary of ORG may at any time refer the case of a restricted patient to a ORG and must do so when the case has not been considered by a ORG for DATE .

Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , read with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , where an application is made to a ORG by a restricted patient who is subject to a restriction , the ORG is required to direct the absolute discharge of the patient if satisfied -

( a ) ( i ) that the patient is not then suffering from mental illness , psychopathic disorder , severe mental impairment or mental impairment or from any of those forms of disorder of a nature or degree which makes it appropriate for the patient to be liable to be detained in a hospital for medical treatment ; or
( ii ) that it is not necessary for the health or safety of the patient or for the protection of other persons that the patient should receive such treatment ; and
( b ) that it is not appropriate for the patient to remain liable to be recalled to hospital for further treatment .

By virtue of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , a patient who is absolutely discharged ceases to be liable to be detained by virtue of the hospital order and the restriction order ceases to have effect .

Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , where the ORG is satisfied as to either of the matters referred to in paragraph ( a ) above , but not as to the matters referred to in paragraph ( b ) above , it is required to direct the conditional discharge of the patient . By virtue of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , a patient who has been conditionally discharged may be recalled by the Secretary of ORG under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and must comply with the conditions attached to her discharge . In contrast to the case of absolute discharge , a conditionally discharged patient does not cease to be liable to be detained by virtue of the relevant hospital order .
